Accès rapide aux vidéos

Recherche par intervenant
Recherche par intervenant
Lundi 17 Novembre 2016
Gretty Mirdal (directrice de l'IEA de Paris) Juan Perez (University Valencia) Saadi Lahlou (London School of Economics) Introduction Charlan Nemeth (University of California, Berkeley) The legacy of Serge Moscovici Stamos Papastamou (Panteion University of Social and Political Sciences) The discrete charm of the genetic model of influence and its indirect impact on epistemic level Carlo Michael Sommer (Darmstadt University of Applied Sciences) Minority Influence and Fashion. The Model of Style Transformation Amber M. Gaffney (Humboldt State University) Jiin Jung, William D. Crano, and Michael A. Hogg (Claremont Graduate University) Contexts and Conditions of Outgroup Influence Fanny Lalot, Juan Manuel Falomir-Pichastor and Alain Quiamzade (University of Geneva) The impact of majority and minority social support for pro-environmental values on pro-environmental behaviours Timothy B. Hayes and Wendy Wood (University of Southern California) Minorities, Meanings, and the Structure of Group Influence: Reflecting and Building Upon the Theoretical Contributions of Serge Moscovici Bernard Personnaz (Centre Edgar Morin IIAC EHESS-CNRS) Psychologie sociale et recherches sur l’influence minoritaire Kamilla Khamzina, Elodie Roebroeck and Serge Guimond (Laboratoire de Psychologie Sociale et Cognitive, Blaise Pascal University, Clermont-Ferrand) Connecting social representation research with minority influence Andreea Ernst-Vintila (Paris-Ouest-Nanterre-la-Défense University) Yechiel Klar (Tel Aviv University) Is There a Social Psychology of Historic Grievances and Intergroup Conflict in the Age of ‘Radicalisation’? Marie Personnaz (Paris-Ouest-Nanterre-la-Défense University - Centre Edgar Morin IIAC EHESS-CNRS) De la polarisation à la radicalisation Babette Gekeler (Institute for Medical Psychology, Charité University Hospitals, Berlin) Kathrin Friederici (Humboldt University, Berlin) Understanding Complexity in Social Engagement with Multiculturalism: why a Multimethod Approach is needed to unravel the Contention with ‘Differences’ Jorge Correia Jesuino (Instituto Superior de Ciências Sociais e Políticas (ISCSP), University of Lisbon) To a semiotic approach to Serge Moscovici’s thinking
Mardi 18 Novembre 2016
Dorra Ben Alaya (Tunis El Manar University) For a «psychology of our «culture» Sabine Caillaud (Paris-Descartes University) How «human history of nature» and the theory of minorities shed light on the dialogical part of social representations. The case of psychologists addressing ecological issues Inari Sakki, Rusten Menard and EEmeli Hakoköngäs Sakki (University of Helsinki) The formation processes re-visited – the importance of naturalized representations Juliet Foster (University of Cambridge) Society and Theory in Social Psychology: a reconsideration Fabrice Buschini (Sorbonne Nouvelle - Paris 3 University) Diffusion, propagation, propagande : et après ? L’effusion, un nouveau mode de communication médiatique pour l’étude des représentations sociales
Mardi 18 Novembre 2016 (Session publique)
George Gaskel (London School of Economics) What and why questions in social representations: securing Moscovici’s legacy John Rijsman (University of Tilburg) Experimental social psychology is not a science of discovery, but an art of theatrical reflection Saadi Lahlou (London School of Economics) Future issues. The analysis of behaviour Themis Apostolidis (University of Aix-Marseille) Future issues: Methods and themes Nikos Kalampalikis (Lumière Lyon 2 University) Future issues: On forms of social thinking Juan A. Pérez (University of Valencia) Future isues: Active minorities vs. Victimized minorities: An Unfinished Task Denise Jodelet (EHESS) Future issues. Applications of Social representations to education and health

Small meeting EASP 2016
Participants

Small meeting EASP 2016 - Participants
La version pdf du programme de l'EASP 2016 est disponible ici.

Le Small Meeting EASP s'est déroulé les 17 et 18 Novembre 2016.

Il a été tenu en l'honneur de Serge Moscovici (1925-2014) et ses contributions aux sciences sociales en général et à la psychologie sociale en particulier.

Voici la liste des participants ainsi que leurs fiches, par ordre alphabétique.

  • Antoine Cordelois, phD in Cognitive sciences - Freelance, France
    [Scientific concil- Invited member] Antoine Cordelois - Freelance, France

    Liens

    • Page personnelle
    • Zotero

    • Mendeley

    Bibliographie

  • Nikos Kalampalikis, Directeur de recherches, phD - Université Lyon 2, France
    [Steering committee] Nikos Kalampalikis - Université Lyon 2, France

    Liens

    [Steering committee] Saadi Lahlou - London School of Economics, England
